top_comment.text:
#teamcatmojo  Great tips as always Jackson -- thank you! My cat Cap'n Jack 
is only a fraidy cat when I have guests. He's terrified of the doorbell or 
knocks at the door. If it weren't for the photos I take of Little Jack, 
family and friends don't even believe he exists -- they've never ever seen 
him! My other cat Joey is more social -- he'll come out to observe guests 
and allow certain people to touch him or play with him. But Jack is simply 
terrified. How can I help him overcome his fear of people?﻿
top_comment.author: Jeanie Williams

comments.text:
At least I know I'm not alone.  Mordred will run if the phone rings!  All 
three will disappear very quickly when a strange car pulls into the 
driveway - or the garbage truck stops to pick up the trash.  I had a 
carpenter build a "wall" under the bed so the cats can't get there, but 
Mordred's favorite place to hide is under the comforter on the bed - no way 
to block *that* off.  <sigh> He's 13 this year, so I guess it is what it is 
- but knowing I'm not alone does help.
comments.author: maerlynii

comments.text:
I have the same issue. My 11 month old Russian blue likes me and ONLY me. 
Hides from my mom and completely takes off whenever a guest arrives.
comments.author: Run Ally Run

comments.text:
same story...we have a 16 year old girl who is fine with my wife two other 
cats and me, but runs for the upstairs bedroom the minute guests arrive. 
 she usually just hangs out on the bed up there.  if somehow guests come in 
before she can get up the stairs, her tail puffs up and she slinks low to 
the ground around the edges of the room to the stairs.  I hate that people 
in the house cause her so much stress.
comments.author: John Tancsik

comments.text:
This is exactly my situation.  I have five strictly indoor cats, all from 
the same litter, and I've had them since they were young kittens.  They've 
never ever been through anything that would make them afraid, but like 
yours, they immediately disappear if anyone comes into the house.  They're 
super friendly with each other, my husband and me.  My two best friends 
have never seen them...only photos.   I have a big house so there are lots 
of rooms in which to hide.  I wish Jackson would address this issue.  I 
know other cats who run to greet anyone who comes to visit, but mine just 
disappear.
comments.author: JoAnn Platt

comments.text:
Mine doesn't hide - he runs. He gets along great with the other cats but 
rejects all human contact. He runs.
comments.author: cattails1000

top_comment.text:
Jackson i have an important question for you. How does one get an abused 
cat to trust the other person? Weather it was abused by its owner the owner 
repented, felt bad wanted to build a better relationship cries himself to 
sleep at night wishing he'd treat his or her cat better, or if the cat was 
rescued from an abused home. Either or. How could each party correct the 
damage done?﻿
top_comment.author: classicgamelover1985

comments.text:
I've had abused cats in the past. What worked for me was making sure they 
saw me put the food in the bowl and then stroking them as they ate. They 
will run at first, but over time the cat sees you won't hurt them and they 
are getting something good at the same time. It builds the idea you are the 
good one who brings food. Try giving treats too. Show the treat, get the 
cat to come in the room with you then put it on the floor near you. 
Eventually you will be able to hand-feed treats which strengthens the bond. 
Just remember it takes a long time to get an abused animal to trust you.So 
give kitty as long as kitty needs for each step.
comments.author: Cindy Bird

comments.text:
IMO only loving kindness over time. Good luck to you in your endeavor, I 
truely hope you get a breakthru.  =)
comments.author: TemeryN

top_comment.text:
Blocking of a spot to hide is a big mistake. The best thing to do from my 
experience is to let them come out from their own, and if they do so - 
leave the cat alone. if you ignore the cat instead of staring at it as it 
comes out your cat will feel alot more comfortable.﻿
top_comment.author: enjOi47

comments.text:
Elizabeth, you leave then alone and let them explore on their own, so they 
get use to the house and dont feel cornered
comments.author: Inch MC

comments.text:
I think Jackson's right ur wrong cuz if you leave them alone how r u 
supposed to use the toys DUUUUUH
comments.author: Elizabeth Benefield

top_comment.text:
My cat is a feral. She walks around the house confidently, but she gets 
spooked over loud noises or strange people and she will hide until the 
person is gone or the sound stops.﻿
top_comment.author: newbirth35

comments.text:
+Kingportable She's feral, not just insecure. She never had human contact 
until I came along and now she is bonded to me. She eventually warmed up to 
my roommate because he gives her milk. She runs from all other people and 
hides under the bed. She has a tall cat tree, but she almost never climbs 
to the top unless there's a spider on the ceiling or something. She spends 
her days either sleeping on the middle level of the tree (about waist 
height) or on my bed.
comments.author: newbirth35

comments.text:
+gammerlaan Maybe your cat is insecure as Jackson says you might need to 
"catify" this is putting ways for your cat to get high and verticle this 
allows cats to feel empowered, more confident and less insecure.
comments.author: Kingportable

comments.text:
Make sure strange people introduce themselves properly. No loud noises, No 
sudden moves. Maybe a friend can help you with this..
comments.author: gammerlaan

comments.text:
Hi newbirth. Cats generally are not very fond of sudden noises. It offsets 
them.
comments.author: gammerlaan

comments.text:
yeah i have a cat like this. i think we are cool with each other 
considering he lets me pet him and dose not run from me like he will with 
most people (probably i'm one of the only 2 that feed the cats >_<)
comments.author: Kinzuko

comments.text:
+Fan
Thanks so much for the responds I will never give up in him :)  Funny thing 
is he is great w/me sleeps w/me, we wrestle so funny but as soon as he 
hears something hes out of here !!!
comments.author: Trish Ward

comments.text:
+Trish Ward I think Jackson Galaxy do answer people's questions through 
webcam. Maybe you can have a go. I may suggest you spend time with your 
cat, play with him and pet him. It can help easing some of his energy and 
stress away. One of my adopted cat freaked out when I brought him home. He 
seemed like a total strayed. He was sacred to be petted. Not interested in 
treats. Play really rough with other cats, so now only the big fluffy 
fellow would play with him.(but don't know why he was much more friendly in 
shelter.) It took him about two weeks to be comfortable with my room which 
he was the only cat in the room at that time. Then took him a month to step 
out of the room. And another few months not to attach with my room. After 
another few months, finally I can pet him once in a while. After a year, he 
would lay his head on my hand and rub it. Still don't like my hand to be 
higher than his head. So, it really takes times, efforts, patience and 
persistence to help your cat. Things I learnt was keep trying but don't 
push them too hard. I was still a cat beginner at that time. Even my 
experienced friend started to give up, I just have faith that cats always 
have a soft side and he is my responsibility since I took him home. So 
please never give up. Good luck.
comments.author: Fan

comments.text: +TheGFeather Thanks so much :)
comments.author: Trish Ward

comments.text:
I know the feeling. You are doing the best that you can and it does make a 
difference. Nature works on its own time. It's a pain in the backside that 
way. Try not to feel bad for him. You have given him a warm, safe home with 
all the food and water he needs. If you hadn't, he'd be in a far worse 
situation. Hold onto that. You're doing just fine.
comments.author: TheGFeather

comments.text:
+TheGFeather
I did buy this Kong hut bed that is all covered except for the front he 
wanted no parts or it :(  I swear thats when this all happened after I got 
him fixed? I feel like I dont even have a pet I see him like 3x's a day and 
I am so so patient w/him constantly talking to him even when I cant find 
him.. I just feel so bad for him..
comments.author: Trish Ward

comments.text:
I made my cat a hiding place that I could control out of a carrier with a 
door that goes on and off easily. When he was hiding there, I only ever 
invaded the entrance, with food in my hand and he uses that as his safe 
place now. I wouldn't worry too much about freaking him out on the short 
term, so long as you give him a place to hide that's his without question.

My big turn around was when I got my guy fixed. I don't know if you've done 
that yet, but it could make a big difference.
comments.author: TheGFeather

comments.text:
+TheGFeather Thanks for the encouragment I give him the raw chicken treats 
as soon as he eats them it off to hidding... Im afraid if I do what Jackson 
says and block off hiding places I will freak him out so BAD !
comments.author: Trish Ward

comments.text:
+Trish Ward
Lots and lots of patience... and high value food treats. Whatever your cat 
likes the best is the thing to use. Only leave the food out when you are 
around and where you can see it. Even my year old feral would only let 36 
hours go by before his hunger overcame his fear. Make the connection 
between yummy food and you obvious. I worked with Macavity for over 6 
months before he let me touch him without immediately retreating. Two 
months on, and he is cuddled on my bed every night. He still retreats and 
gets started or overwhelmed by things, but he comes out sooner each time. I 
expect he'll always be more prone to retreat than confrontation. I think 
that is part of his personality as much as his conditioning.
comments.author: TheGFeather

comments.text:
Cat's hold no grudges.  He will indeed be a great pet, he just has a low 
tolerance to a lot of stimulation.  Good luck!
comments.author: Mel Anderson

comments.text:
I too rescued a feral kitten about 5 weeks old,  He is now 14 mos old. He 
is also very easily startled at ANY sound and will not tolerate anyone 
other than my husband, daughter and myself.  Only problem is he doesn't run 
and hide, he attacks.  He is very territorial and aggressive and has some 
male dominance issues with my husband (he's been neutered) which usually 
ends with my husband bleeding.  He's a biter and scratches when scared, 
angry,  happy ect...( I will never declaw a cat) He was the sweetest kitten 
but around 6 mos he started attacking us, our feet and ankles and hands and 
stopped sitting on our laps and sleeping on us.  He will jump up on my 
husband's leg with all claws dug in  but wont do it to me.  I tell people 
that he thinks he's the King but I'm the Kings MOTHER so I'm treated as 
such (though I also have my battle scars). By my watching Jason's show and 
following his ideas Rascal has improved alot, except the thing with other 
people and my husband is still fair game.  People think I'm crazy for 
keeping him but I love him and know he would have to be put down if I did. 
 When he was neutered they had to knock him out while he was in his carrier 
before they could handle him. They trimmed his claws and put the Kitty Kaps 
on for me which he promptly started chewing off.   I can't have him put 
under every time he needs his claws trimmed  so don't know what I'm going 
to do about that (or when he needs his next shots). He is a beautiful tabby 
w/tufts on his ears. He loves to play and can be affectionate on his terms. 
 I just feel bad about what his life started out like and that I probably 
did things wrong without realizing it.  I have never had a cat like this 
one.  Wish Jason was in Pa. I would definitely want his opinion and 
expertise.  Sorry for rambling but any input would be appreciated.
comments.author: Dawn Love

comments.text:
I also have the same problem with my cat Cinder also feral, but he gets so 
scared sometimes I dont see him for days !!  Breaks my heart any advice ?
comments.author: Trish Ward

comments.text:
Lucky was born feral and rescued when he was only about 4 weeks old.  His 
mother had been killed by a coyote.  He is the same as your cats.  He's 
fine with me, but hides if the doorbell rings and if anyone comes to the 
house.  He is strictly an indoor cat.  He's afraid of the outdoors too.  
He's okay with other cats, but hates the neighbor's dog when he visits.
comments.author: Kathy Rehus

comments.text:
I have three siblings that are now 3 1/2 years.  Their mother was feral and 
they were born in a barn (really)!  They act just like your cat does.  They 
do not like strangers in the house and will hide when someone knocks on the 
door.  They spook easily.  But they are my babies and I love them even 
though they are jumpy and paranoid.  They are indoor-outdoor cats and enjoy 
their time outside as long as nothing spooks them.  Haha.  However dogs and 
other cats don't spook them but bicycles and people do.
comments.author: Mel Anderson

top_comment.text:
My cat is fine with being about in the house. It's definitely her house. 
The minute a stranger enters the house, she skitters into hiding. I've 
tried playing with her and soothing her with other people around, but she's 
still anxious. She wasn't like this at all as a kitten.﻿
top_comment.author: High Stepping Night Owl

comments.text:
Exactly. That's exactly how she is. With significant others, she will get 
used to them after a month of regular visits. It's still major work, 
though, and everyone who knew her as a kitten can't believe she doesn't 
recognize them now.
comments.author: High Stepping Night Owl

comments.text:
My one of two cats, Howard, is the same way. Totally loving and confidant 
when it's just my wife and me at home but when a "stranger" comes in he is 
into hiding. I can pet him all I want and he never and I mean never gets 
aggressive towards anyone. He'll stay in hiding for hours after the person 
is gone then he's back to normal. I feel so bad because he's such an 
awesome cat and I want others too not only see him but see who he really is.
comments.author: bojengels1

top_comment.text:
I watch all your TV shows and have never seen you do something in regards 
to a cats eminent death.   My Maine Coon cat Max, is 16 yrs old.   About 4 
years ago, he was diagnosed with Renal Failure.   He now weighs 5# - his 
bones stick out, does not seem in pain and of course we totally pamper him. 
He eats constantly and drinks lots of water.   When he goes I will have him 
cremated.   Meanwhile, when the time does come, if he should die at night, 
etc. and I find he has expired ....... what specifically, do I do.﻿
top_comment.author: Nark R

comments.text:
+TemeryN  thank you so much - I know "I" will be a basket case then.   I 
talked to my vet.
comments.author: Nark R

comments.text:
+Nark R  the body should be ok for about 24 hrs in normal (70 ish degree) 
weather inside your home, which should give you time to find a vet that's 
open or could at least take your pet off your hands until cremation time 
(hold him somewhere for you). You might feel better if you call your vet 
and talk to them about the procedure, ask them "what do I do if...." (most 
vets have an emergency number for after hours, my vet boards as well so 
they are kind of 24 hr, not for all services of course but for some things).
comments.author: TemeryN

comments.text:
+TemeryN - Thank you for your comments regarding my kitty's sunset time.  I 
do have a box for him, but I guess I was thinking ....if he died at night 
or over a holiday or weekend.   I had heard putting him in the freezer, 
which I could not do..
comments.author: Nark R

comments.text:
I feel your pain and I'm so sorry your loved one is in his sunset time. 
Specifically (sorry tears are happening as I type) keep a box handy or use 
his carrier to take him to your local vet for cremation if the awful should 
happen and you find him expired  =(  

I gave mine low sodium chicken broth for the last few months (but he had 
cancer and could not digest enough nutrients out of the food before it went 
thru his processes), still he loved it as a treat.
comments.author: TemeryN

captions.text:
So last time we
got together I was

talking about the
challenge line.

Comfort, challenge, comfort,
challenge, comfort, challenge.

Now today we're going to be
talking about 'fraidy cats.

Raising them up, pushing
them over that line,

letting them know it's
better on the other side.
Are you psyched?
Because I am, man.
Let's talk 'fraidy cats.
One, two, let's get catified.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Let's talk about
how we get our cats
to go from 'fraidy to mojo.

First thing is your best
friend and min, right here,
it's basically painter's tape.

And the coolest
thing about blue tape

is that as you can
see it's sticky

but it doesn't
stick really, right?

So you can put it on
the furniture here.
You can put it on your guitar.

You can put it on your forehead
and you can take it right off.

Every time you've identified
your cats challenge line

you put one of these
suckers on the floor.

Now we know that today we're
going to put a bowl of food
right there on that line.

Tomorrow, we're going
to reset that line,

and I don't even care
if it's by three inches.

But we are going to get
her to start coming out.

As we're moving the cats
through challenge line work,

further and further
out, a couple things
we're going to do.

First thing we're going
to do is gradually

block off the places that
they're calling home.

In order for them to be that
best version of themselves

we've got to say, you
know what, I will give you

all the love that you
could possibly desire,

all the comfort that you
need, but not under there.

Block off a little
bit of that under.

Alright, I'm not saying that
one day your cat wakes up

and you have shoved
pillows underneath the bed,

or you have removed
the under of the bed.

It's something that
happens gradually, right?

Now, as your cat has cleared
that first initial challenge

line, now we start
bringing out the toys, man.

And again the toys that have
the rods, the fishing pole toys,

the ones with feathers,
or mice at the end.
Those toys.

Really crucial if they
move towards the middle

of that floor and they
kill, when I say kill,
they pounce on that toy.

That from that moment
on, they own that spot.

And we know that the
key to mojo is what?
Ownership of territory.
Ownership of territory.
Boom, cat mojo supreme.

And we have taken a wall
flower and turned them

into the best version of
themselves that they can be.
Now a bit of a disclaimer.

I'm not talking about
morphing your cat into someone
they're not.

Don't expect your cat
to be someone else.

Expect you cat to be the
best version of themselves
that they can be.
And that's our job.

To start realizing that
every time she pokes her out

from under that bed,
good things happen.
Don't feed under the bed.

It is not doing your cat
any favors whatsoever.

If they know that at some point
you are just going to cave

and you are going to put
food in their hiding zone?

Again, not doing
them any favors.
Now that's the truth, Ruth.
So your homework is as follows.

Number one, lead
them out with food
and the challenge line of tape.

The second thing
you're going to do

is block off the
unders very slowly.

Every day a little bit more
of that challenge line pushed.

And the third
thing is, make sure

through interactive play
and the replication of hunt,

catch, kill, eat that you
get that mojo unleashed.

The mojo gets unleashed,
the wall flower
comes out of hiding.
Alright folks, that's it for me.

Don't forget, find
me anywhere, man.

I'm on Twitter, instagram,
Facebook, where else,
Google plus, YouTube.

And don't forget
with your homework,
share it with the rest of us.

The only way that we're
all going to learn

is through discussion,
conversation,
group revelations.

Hashtag TeamCatMojo, that way
I'll see it, we'll all see it.
Follow that conversation.

Because remember something,
folks, if you make a discovery

and you give it to the rest
of us we can save lives.
It is that simple.
It is.
All right until next time folks.

All light, all love
and all mojo to you.
Love you.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: 3 Steps To Make Your Cat More Social
